PetProgress — iPhone Lock-Screen Habits with an Evolving Pet. PetProgress turns the Lock Screen into your control panel: see the current hour’s task, tap ✓ / ✕ / ‹ / › to complete, skip, or page tasks without opening the app, and watch a pet evolve or de-evolve as XP crosses thresholds. The experience uses interactive widgets powered by App Intents, plus hourly, timeline-driven updates so the widget stays fresh. State is shared between app and widget to keep everything in sync. 
Apple Developer

Apple Developer
+2

Audience & value. For routine-driven people who dislike notification clutter, PetProgress keeps focus glanceable and actionable; the pet’s visible progress adds emotion and streak pressure that nudges consistency.
Platform & scope. iPhone-only app with Lock-Screen widgets in inline, circular, and rectangular families, plus a lightweight app for settings and (optional) a simple “today” list. 
Apple Developer
+1

Core experience. (1) Lock-Screen actions: four buttons—Complete, Skip, Previous, Next—execute App Intents directly from the widget, mutate shared state, and trigger a scoped timeline reload so the UI reflects changes promptly. (2) Nearest-hour window: the widget always shows the task closest to the current hour; a configurable Grace Minutes window lets a task remain “current” briefly into the next hour. Updates come from an AppIntentTimelineProvider scheduled at hourly boundaries, with explicit reloads after actions. (3) Pet evolution & de-evolution: a stage image is chosen from XP thresholds; completing tasks adds XP; missed tasks at midnight + grace subtract XP, and the next render shows the new stage. (4) True sync: both targets use an App Group for small shared data so the app and widget always see the same truth. 
Apple Developer
+4
Apple Developer
+4
Apple Developer
+4

What the user sees. Rectangular: left—pet stage art; right—current task title with a tiny hour badge; row of ‹ ✓ ✕ ›. Circular: pet face/progress for quick glance. Inline: ultra-compact “Task • hh:00 • Stage N”. All are designed for Lock-Screen accessory families. 
Apple Developer

Behavioral rules. Rollover occurs at midnight + Grace Minutes: undone tasks become “missed,” XP penalties apply, and the pet may de-evolve; the widget reflects this on its next timeline render. Actions request a reload of this widget kind; system-managed timelines ensure regular updates while conserving power. 
Apple Developer
+1

Data (conceptual). Small, local models shared through the App Group: Task {id, title, dueHour, dayKey, isDone}; PetState {xp, stageIndex}; Settings {graceMinutes, privacyPolicyURL}; WidgetViewState {currentIndex}. Stored as tiny JSON blobs and/or UserDefaults(suiteName:). 
Apple Developer

Settings & privacy. In-app Grace Minutes (0–30) with a short explainer and an in-app Privacy Policy link; fully offline—no accounts or cloud in v1.
Success (v1). From the Lock Screen, users complete/skip/page tasks without opening the app; pet and task visuals feel fresh at hourly boundaries and after actions; iPhone-only packaging with clean icons; shared state remains consistent across launches and days.
